Authors:
Chandrika Ramadugu, Bernard E. Pfeil, Keremane L.
Manjunath, Richard F. Lee, Ivan J Maureira-Butler, Mikeal L. Roose
Title:
Coalescence Simulation Testing of Hybridization versus
Lineage Sorting in Citrus (Rutaceae) using Six Nuclear Genes
Keywords:
Hybridization, lineage sorting, paralogy, gene
duplication, coalescence, nuclear DNA, multi-locus phylogeny, gene tree,
species tree
Abstract:
Processes such as hybridization, gene duplication and
loss, and the sorting of ancestral polymorphisms can give genes
different histories to the species that carry them. Untangling which of
these processes can explain incongruence among gene trees is difficult,
but has recently been addressed using methods that simulate the
coalescent. We used a method previously described for two gene trees and
extend it here to utilize a third gene tree. We show that the
sensitivity of the test improves markedly with an acceptable type 1
error rate. Using sequences from low copy nuclear genes in Citrus
(Rutaceae), a group of plants with a complex past that includes known
and suspected hybrids, we were able to diagnose cases of hybridization
previously detected by SSRs using population genetic methods, but also
cases where these markers failed to do so. Of six gene trees examined in
Citrus, we used the most resolved three for the coalescence test, but
note that the remaining genes show patterns that were consistent with
the conclusions from the test. The consistent patterns observed among
the six loci also allowed us to rule out mistaken orthology (caused by
gene duplication and loss) in most cases where the null hypothesis of
lineage sorting was rejected.
